Lecture

W.E.B. Du Bois Institute Colloquium Series

Ethnicity, Inc.

:: :: ::

Free and open to the public

:: :: ::

Wed., Sep. 5, 2012, 12pm
Thompson Room, Barker Center, 12 Quincy Street, Cambridge

:: :: ::

Speakers:

Jean Comaroff, professor of African and African American studies and of anthropology, Oppenheimer Fellow in African Studies;

John Comaroff, professor of African and African American studies and of anthropology, Oppenheimer Fellow in African Studies

:: :: ::

Sponsored by the W. E. B. Du Bois Institute for African and African American Research

:: :: ::

Note The politics of cultural identity, far from receding with the modernity, appears to have taken on new force in the wake of the cold war -- especially with the triumphal rise of neoliberal capitalism on a global scale. This has yielded efforts to explain the continued salience of ethnicity in a "new" world order that, in the late 1980s and early 1990s, was widely predicted to dissolve difference in the face of global flows of people, objects, currencies, signs, styles, desires. Less attention has been paid to a subtle shift in the nature of ethnicity: its commodification. This lecture is devoted to showing that, increasingly, ethnic groups are acting like corporations that own a "natural" copyright to their "culture" and "cultural products" -- framed as heritage and indigenous knowledge -- which they protect, by recourse to the law, and on which they capitalize in much the same way as do incorporated businesses. Why is this occurring? What are its political, economic, social, and ethical consequences? How is it transforming the nature of ethnicity and citizenship in the nation-state? What are its theoretical implications for understanding such foundational social science concepts as culture and identity?
